title: [$250] Optimize BaseSelectionList component performance

labels.name: Reviewing
labels.description: Has a PR in review

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Weekly
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

labels.name: AutoAssignerNewDotQuality
labels.description: Used to assign quality issues to engineers

body:
Coming from [here](https://expensify.slack.com/archives/C05LX9D6E07/p1757938701761199) ### Background The BaseSelectionList component is a critical UI component used throughout the Expensify app for rendering searchable lists of selectable items like reports, users or policies. Profiling shows severe slowdowns when rendering large datasets. The main culprit is excessive re-renders triggered by unstable object references and unnecessary state updates. In particular, flattenedSections variable performs heavy computations and is invoked 8 times, with each call averaging ~200ms. ### Problem When users open screens with SelectionList component containing large amount of options (e.g. Start chat), then frequent re-renders and repeated flattenedSections calculations occur, which creates performance bottlenecks and slows down screen access. ### Solution Implement stable array reference for selectedItems prop by using CONST.EMPTY_ARRAY to prevent unnecessary re-renders when no items are selected. This avoids creating a new array on each render, which previously caused React to detect a prop change even when the content was identical. Additionally, convert the itemHeights from state to ref, since it’s only used for layout calculations and doesn’t need to trigger re-renders. These changes preserve functionality while eliminating unnecessary render cycles, reducing BaseSelectionList render time on iOS (24k options, “Start chat” screen) from ~1.6s to ~200ms.

Click Add cards and proceed to add a Direct feed card by either using a real card from one of the bank options or click Other to add a faux BA via Plaid flow (only on staging server). 3. Once BA flow is completed, on the Statement close date RHP click Submit to complete BA addition. 4. On the Company cards page, click [+] Assign card and assign card to yourself > on Choose a transaction start date step keep default (From the beginning) > click Assign card. 5. Navigate to Reports page, click Expenses and verify that you see multiple expenses originating from the company card assigned in the previous step. 6. title: [$250] Optimize `getOptionData`

labels.name: Reviewing
labels.description: Has a PR in review

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Weekly
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

body:
### Background The Expensify app’s left-hand navigation (LHN) sidebar lists reports. Each report needs option metadata for display. This involves filtering participants (e.g., hiding the current user, handling visibility rules) and tracking report attributes for React re-renders. The `getOptionData` function prepares this data and is called frequently. `OptionRowLHNData` wraps it in `useMemo` to avoid unnecessary recalculations, but the current setup still causes performance bottlenecks. ### Problem When user is in Most Recent mode, and the sidebar renders options for a large amount of reports, it calls `getParticipantsAccountIDsForDisplay` multiple times with different parameters and tracks unnecessary dependencies in React’s useMemo hook, which causes redundant computation of participant filtering logic and unnecessary re-renders when irrelevant report attributes change, which prevents the sidebar from rendering efficiently. ### Solution Reduce `getParticipantsAccountIDsForDisplay` function calls by extracting part of the logic responsible for filtering the results for different use cases into separate function so it’s not needed to call the original function multiple times. Additionally, remove `reportAttributes` from the `useMemo` dependency array. `getOptionData` only uses three properties from it: `reportName`, `brickRoadStatus` and `reportErrors`. The first two are already included in the array, and we should explicitly check whether the `reportErrors` object has changed to avoid unnecessary calls. On iOS, when creating a new chat with ~2k reports and ~28k personal details, `getOptionData` time went from **~900ms** to **~150ms.**
